{{See also|Astronomical symbols}} {{astrology}} [[Symbol]]s used in [[astrology]] overlap with those used in [[astronomy]] because of the historical overlap between the two subjects. Frequently used symbols include signs of the [[zodiac]] and for the [[classical planet]]s. These have their origin in medieval Byzantiny, but in their current form are a product of the European [[Renaissance astrology|Renaissance]]. Other symbols for [[astrological aspect]]s are used in various astrological traditions.
==History and origin==
Symbols for the [[classical planet]]s, zodiac signs, aspects, lots, and the lunar nodes appear in the medieval Byzantine codices in which many ancient horoscopes were preserved.<ref name=neugebauer-1975>{{cite book | title = A history of ancient mathematical astronomy | last = Neugebauer | first = Otto | date = 1975 | pages = 788–789 }}</ref> In the original papyri of these Greek horoscopes, there were found a circle with the glyph representing shine([[File:Old symbol for sun.svg|x15px|old sun symbol]]) for the Sun and a crescent for the Moon.<ref name=neugebauer-1987>{{cite book | title = Greek Horoscopes | last1 = Neugebauer | first1 = Otto | last2 = Van Hoesen | first2 = H. B. | date = 1987 | pages = 1, 159, 163 }}</ref> The written symbols for Mercury, Venus, Jupiter, and Saturn have been traced to forms found in late Greek papyri.<ref name=jones-1999>{{cite book | title = Astronomical papyri from Oxyrhynchus | last = Jones | first = Alexander | date = 1999 | pages = 62–63 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=8MokzymQ43IC }} "It is now possible to trace the medieval symbols for at least four of the five planets to forms that occur in some of the latest papyrus horoscopes ([ [[Oxyrhynchus Papyri|P.Oxy.]] ] 4272, 4274, 4275 [...]). That for Jupiter is an obvious monogram derived from the initial letter of the Greek name. Saturn's has a similar derivation [...] but underwent simplification. The ideal form of Mars' symbol is uncertain, and perhaps not related to the later circle with an arrow through it. Mercury's is a stylized caduceus."</ref> The symbols for Jupiter and Saturn are identified as monograms of the initial letters of the corresponding Greek names, and the symbol for Mercury is a stylized [[caduceus]].<ref name=jones-1999 /> A. S. D. Maunder finds antecedents of the planetary symbols in earlier sources, used to represent the gods associated with the classical planets. ''Bianchini's [[planisphere]]'', produced in the 2nd century,<ref name=imss>{{cite web |url=http://brunelleschi.imss.fi.it/galileopalazzostrozzi/object/BianchinisPlanisphere.html |title=Bianchini's planisphere |publisher=Istituto e Museo di Storia della Scienza (Institute and Museum of the History of Science) |location=Florence, Italy |accessdate=2010-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030005806/http://brunelleschi.imss.fi.it/galileopalazzostrozzi/object/BianchinisPlanisphere.html |archivedate=2009-10-30 }}</ref> shows Greek personifications of planetary gods charged with early versions of the planetary symbols: Mercury has a [[caduceus]]; Venus has, attached to her necklace, a cord connected to another necklace; Mars, a spear; Jupiter, a staff; Saturn, a scythe; the Sun, a [[circlet]] with rays radiating from it; and the Moon, a headdress with a crescent attached.<ref name=maunder>{{cite journal | last = Maunder | first = A. S. D. | date = 1934 | title = The origin of the symbols of the planets | journal = The Observatory | volume = 57 | pages = 238–247 | bibcode = 1934Obs....57..238M }}</ref> A diagram in Johannes Kamateros' 12th century ''Compendium of Astrology'' shows the Sun represented by the circle with a ray, Jupiter by the letter ''zeta'' (the initial of [[Zeus]], Jupiter's counterpart in [[Greek mythology]]), Mars by a shield crossed by a spear, and the remaining classical planets by symbols resembling the modern ones, without the cross-mark seen in modern versions of the symbols.<ref name=maunder /> The modern sun symbol, pictured as a circle with a dot (☉), first appeared in the Renaissance.<ref name=neugebauer-1987 />
Symbols for Uranus and Neptune were created shortly after their discovery. For Uranus, two variant symbols are seen. One symbol, [[File:Uranus symbol.svg|15px|Uranus]], invented by [[Johann Gottfried Koehler|J. G. Köhler]] and refined by [[Johann Elert Bode|Bode]], was intended to represent the newly discovered metal [[platinum]]; since platinum, sometimes confused with white gold, was found by chemists mixed with iron, the symbol for platinum combines the alchemical symbols for [[iron]], ♂, and [[gold]], ☉.<ref name=bode-uranus>{{cite book | title = Von dem neu entdeckten Planeten | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ZqA5AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA95 | last = Bode | first = J. E. | date = 1784 | pages = 95–96 }}</ref><ref name=gould-uranus>{{cite book | title = Report on the history of the discovery of Neptune | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=uyANAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA5 | last = Gould | first = B. A. | publisher = Smithsonian Institution | date = 1850 | page = 5 }}</ref> Another symbol, [[File:Uranus's astrological symbol.svg|15px|Uranus]], was suggested by Lalande in 1784. In a letter to Herschel, Lalande described it as "un globe surmonté par la première lettre de votre nom" ("a globe surmounted by the first letter of your name").<ref name="Francisca">{{Cite journal|author=Francisca Herschel|date=1917|title=The meaning of the symbol H+o for the planet Uranus|bibcode=1917Obs....40..306H|work=The Observatory}}<!--|accessdate=2007-08-05--></ref> After Neptune was discovered, the Bureau des Longitudes proposed the name Neptune and the familiar trident for the planet's symbol.<ref name=gould-neptune>{{cite book | title = Report on the history of the discovery of Neptune | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=uyANAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA22 | last = Gould | first = B. A. | publisher = Smithsonian Institution | date = 1850 | page = 22 }}</ref>
The astrological symbols for the first three objects discovered at the beginning of the 19th century —[[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]], [[2 Pallas|Pallas]], and [[3 Juno|Juno]]—were also created after their discovery. Firstly, they were listed as planets, and half a century later, renamed as Asteroids. Shortly after [[Giuseppe Piazzi]]'s discovery of [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]], a group of astronomers ratified the name, proposed by the discoverer, and chose the sickle as a symbol of the planet.<ref name=bode-1801>{{cite book | editor = Bode, J. E. | title = Berliner astronomisches Jahrbuch führ das Jahr 1804 | date = 1801 | pages = 97–98 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6GElAQAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA98 }}</ref> The symbol for Pallas, the spear of [[Athena|Pallas Athena]], was invented by Baron Franz Xaver von Zach, and introduced in his ''Monatliche Correspondenz zur Beförderung der Erd- und Himmels-Kunde''.<ref name=mcbeh-v6>von Zach, Franz Xaver (1802). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=nR04AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA95 Monatliche Correspondenz zur Beförderung der Erd- und Himmels-Kunde, Volume 6]''. pp. 95-96.</ref> [[Karl Ludwig Harding]], who discovered and named Juno, assigned to it the symbol of a scepter topped with a star.<ref name=mcbeh-v10>{{cite book | title = Monatliche Correspondenz zur Beförderung der Erd- und Himmels-Kunde | volume = 10 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=vnIEAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA1-PA471 | last = von Zach | first = Franz Xaver | date = 1804 | page = 471 }}</ref>
The modern astrological symbol for [[4 Vesta|Vesta]] was created by [[Eleanor Bach]],<ref name=suberic-asteroid>{{cite web | url = http://www.suberic.net/~dmm/graphics/astro/asteroids.html | title = Asteroid Symbols | accessdate = 2010-05-20 }}</ref> who is credited with pioneering the use of the [[List of exceptional asteroids#Largest by mass|Big Four]] asteroids with the publication of her ''Ephemerides of the Asteroids''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.solsticepoint.com/astrologersmemorial/bach.html |title = Memorial for Astrologer, Eleanor Bach |accessdate = 2010-05-20 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101130075136/http://www.solsticepoint.com/astrologersmemorial/bach.html |archivedate = 2010-11-30 |df = }}</ref> Bach's symbol for Vesta is a simplified version of other representations of Vesta's altar.<ref name=suberic-asteroid /> The original form of the symbol for Vesta, [[File:Simbolo di Vesta.svg|18px|Vesta]], was created by German mathematician [[Carl Friedrich Gauss]]. Olbers, having previously discovered and named one new planet (as the asteroids were then classified), gave Gauss the honor of naming his newest discovery. Gauss decided to name the planet for the goddess [[Vesta (mythology)|Vesta]], and also specified that the symbol should be the altar of the goddess with the [[Sacred fire of Vesta|sacred fire]] burning on it.<ref name=mcbeh-v15>{{cite book | title = Monatliche Correspondenz zur Beförderung der Erd- und Himmels-Kunde | volume = 15 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=_Rw4AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA507 | last = von Zach | first = Franz Xaver | date = 1807 | page = 507 }}</ref><ref name=effemeridi-1809>{{cite book | title = Effemeridi astronomiche di Milano per l'anno 1809 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=LPMNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA100 | last = Carlini | first = Francesco | date = 1808 }}</ref>
[[Pluto]], like Uranus, has multiple symbols in use. One symbol, a [[monogram]] of the letters ''PL'' (which could be interpreted to stand for Pluto or for astronomer [[Percival Lowell]]), was announced with the name of the new planet by the discoverers on May 1, 1930.<ref name=popular-astronomy>{{cite journal | last = Slipher | first = V. M. | date = 1930 | title = The Trans-Neptunian planet | url = http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-journal_query?volume=38&plate_select=NO&page=415&plate=&cover=&journal=PA... | volume = 38 | page = 415 }}</ref> Another symbol, which was popularized in Paul Clancy's astrological publications, is based on the symbol for Mercury, with the circle and arc of Mercury trading positions. This symbol is described by [[Dane Rudhyar]] as "suggest[ing] the planetary character of the Pluto mind by the circle, floating above the open cup." Although, this meaning is readily debatable due to Blavatskian origins, rather than a properly traditional understanding, such as may be found in the hermetic sciences.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.khaldea.com/rudhyar/astroarticles/planetssymbols_5.shtml | title = PART FIVE: Mercury and Pluto | last = Rudhyar | first = Dane | date = 1966 | work = The Planets and their Symbols | accessdate = 2010-05-20 }}</ref>
The symbol for the [[centaur (minor planet)|centaur]] [[2060 Chiron|Chiron]], a key with the letter K (for discoverer [[Charles T. Kowal]]) was proposed by astrologer Al Morrison, who presented the symbol as "an inspiration shared amongst Al H. Morrison, Joelle K.D. Mahoney, and Marlene Bassoff."<ref>{{cite journal | last = Morrison | first = Al H. | date = 1977 | title = Chiron | journal = CAO Times | volume = 3 | page = 57 }}</ref>
The symbol for [[Apparent retrograde motion|retrograde motion]] is ℞, a capital R with a tail stroke.<ref>{{cite book | last = Randall | first = Sidney | title = The ABC of the Old Science of Astrology | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=m1antzbw_DcC&pg=PA14 | date = 2006 | page = 14 | quote = ...the ℞ with the stroke across the tail stands for Retrograde. | isbn = 978-1-59605-920-7 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Lilly | first = William | title = Christian Astrology | date = 1659 | pages = 35, 37 | url = http://www.skyscript.co.uk/texts.html }} A chart with ℞ by a retrograde Jupiter appears on p. 35; on p. 37, describing the construction of the chart, Lilly says: "And because [Jupiter] is noted Retrograde I place the letter R, the better to informe my judgement."</ref><ref>({{cite web |url=http://janetsplan-its.com/info/MercRetro.shtml |title=Mercury Retrograde |last=Booth |first=Janet |work=JanetsPlan-Its.com |date=2005 |accessdate=2010-10-20 |quote=The symbol for retrograde looks like an ”R” with an “X” going through it, the same as the symbol for a prescription. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101114084238/http://janetsplan-its.com/info/MercRetro.shtml |archivedate=2010-11-14 |df= }}</ref> An R with a tail stroke was used to [[Scribal abbreviation|abbreviate]] many words beginning with the letter R; in medical prescriptions, it abbreviated the word ''recipe''<ref name="medical-examiner" /> (from the Latin imperative of ''recipere'' "to take"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.m-w.com/cgi-bin/dictionary?book=Dictionary&va=recipe |title=Recipe definition|publisher=M-w.com |date=2007-04-25 |accessdate=2010-01-22}}</ref>), and in [[missal]]s, an R with a tail stroke marked the responses.<ref name="medical-examiner">{{cite journal | editor = Smith, Frances Gurney | title = The Medical Examiner, and record of medical science | date = 1852 | volume = 8 | page = 804 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1hYCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA804 }}</ref>
==Meanings of the symbols==
=== Astrological planets=== {{further information|Planets in astrology}} The glyphs of the planets are usually (but not always) broken down into four common elements: A circle denoting spirit, a crescent denoting the mind, a cross denoting practical/physical matter and an arrow denoting action or direction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uranian-institute.org/bfglyphs.htm |title=Glyphs of the general astrological and Uranian planets |publisher=Uranian-institute.org |date=2001-10-22 |accessdate=2018-03-22}}</ref>

===Aspects=== {{further information|Astrological aspects}} In [[astrology]], an '''aspect''' is an [[angle]] the [[Planets in astrology|planets]] make to each other in the [[horoscope]], also to the [[ascendant]], [[midheaven]], [[descendant (astrology)|descendant]], [[Imum coeli|lower midheaven]], and other points of astrological interest. The following symbols are used to note aspect:<ref name="L217020">{{cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2017/17020r2-fdbk-extra-aspect-sym.pdf|title=L2/17-020R2: Feedback on Extra Aspect Symbols for Astrology|date=2017-01-24|first=Michel|last=Suignard}}</ref>

however, their usage is very important in [[Vedic astrology]]. The two nodes together are most commonly referred to simply as the '''nodal axis''', the '''lunar nodes''', or the '''Moon's nodes'''. |- |Descending [[node (astronomy)|Node]]||[[File:Southnode-symbol.svg|20px]] || {{huge|☋}} || U+260B |- | [[Plutino]] || [[28978 Ixion|Ixion]]||[[File:Ixion symbol proposal 1.png|20px|Ixion]] || || | style="text-align: left;" | Represents the wheel to which Zeus bound [[Ixion]] according to Greek mythology, as a punishment in Tartarus. |- |[[Scattered disk object]]|| [[42355 Typhon|Typhon]]||[[File:Typhon symbol proposal.svg|70x35px|Typhon]] || || |style="text-align: left;" | Simplified representation of a hurricane, as in Greek mythology Typhon was a divine monster that could create hurricanes with his wings |- | rowspan="2" | [[Small solar system body|Small body]] || [[50000 Quaoar|Quaoar]]||[[File:Quaoar symbol proposal.svg|70x35px|Quaoar]] || || |style="text-align: left;" | Sharp rock art of the Tongva people, in whose mythology it is present the creator god Quaoar, and the letter Q and a canoe.<ref name="/www.suberic.net/~dmm/astro/tno.html"/> |- |[[90377 Sedna|Sedna]]||[[File:Sedna symbol proposal.svg|20px|Sedna]] || {{huge|⯲}} || U+2BF2 | style="text-align: left;" | It consists of the symbols of the [[Inuktitut syllabics]] for 'sa' and 'n', since in this language Sedna is written as 'Sanna' (ᓴᓐᓇ). Besides, it resembles the shape of a marine animal leaping from the water, in alussion to the myth of [[Sedna (mythology)|Sedna]], the [[Inuit]] sea goddess.<ref name="/www.suberic.net/~dmm/astro/tno.html"/> |- | rowspan="3" | [[Alchemical symbol#Three primes|Alchemical 'Three primes']]||Zodiacal modalities:<br>[[Cardinal sign (astrology)|cardinal]] || [[Image:Mercury symbol.svg|28px]] || {{huge|☿}} || U+263F |rowspan="3" style="text-align: left;" | Western astrological symbolism has common early origin with alchemical shorthand glyphs, and planetary divination has long been held in association with alchemy's symbols; the three primes of Paracelsus have been associated with the zodiac sign modalities, and tendencies of their nature in an elementary way to be construed as being mutable (Quick-Silver or Mercury), fixed (Salt) or be cardinal (Sulfur). |- | [[Fixed sign|fixed]] || [[File:Line within circle.svg|25px]] || {{huge|🜔}} || U+1F714 |- | [[Mutable sign|mutable]] || [[Image:Sulphur.svg|16px]] || {{huge|🜍}} || U+1F70D |}

The '''Awareness Course''' is the education programme of the [[Awareness Foundation]]. The course has been described as helping "Christians develop an informed response to the religious and cultural diversity around them by being centered in their faith and secure in their identity."<ref>St. Paul's K Street, Washington: http://www.stpauls-kst.com/node/61{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It is co-written by retired bishop [[Michael Marshall (bishop)|Michael Marshall]] and [[Nadim Nassar]], who is the only Syrian priest in the [[Church of England]].
The Awareness Course has been taught in the [[United Kingdom]], the [[United States of America]], [[Syria]], [[Jordan]], [[Lebanon]] and [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] in the [[Middle East]] and in [[Hong Kong]]. Denominations offering the Awareness Course include the [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic Church]], the [[Church of England]], the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]], the [[Greek Orthodox Church]], [[Presbyterian]], [[Methodist]] and [[Baptist]] churches, Middle Eastern Evangelical churches, and several charismatic evangelical churches in the UK. Teachers are known as "course leaders" and their role is primarily that of a facilitator and motivator rather than lecturer.
== Modules == The Awareness Course comprises a number of course modules or varying lengths:
1. 8 Session DVD Module
Eight sessions designed to last 60 to 90 minutes each depending on the Course Leader. Every session includes two 12 to 16 minute videos presented by Nadim Nassar. The videos are professionally produced and the videos for The Diversity Code feature guest speakers from other Christian traditions (e.g. charismatic evangelical) and Jewish and Islamic scholars.
a. The Diversity Code
Today, diversity is a major issue for us all. The Diversity Code uses a series of ‘Biblical Case Studies’ to reveal the wonderful examples for dealing positively with diversity that Jesus set throughout His life and teachings, as did St Paul. The course also studies the lessons learned by the early Church as she struggled to accept her universal mission.
2. 5 Session Module (Suitable For Lent)
Five sessions designed to last 60 minutes each. Every session includes one 15 minute video presented by Nadim Nassar. The videos are professionally produced and the videos feature guest speakers from other Christian traditions (e.g. charismatic evangelical) and Jewish and Islamic scholars.
a. Living in a Global Village
This shorter course examines how participants can affirm their faith in the midst of a new, globalised world. The sessions cover topics such as hospitality & generosity in faith, preaching the Gospel by living it in our daily lives, and how we can celebrate difference and diversity without having to compromise our faith. Originally marketed as a Lent course, Living in a Global Village is described as being "suitable for any time of the year".
3. Day/Half-Day Workshop
Designed to last either a complete day or half a day according to the Course Leader’s wishes. The workshop includes four 15 minute videos presented by Nadim Nassar. The videos are professionally produced and the videos feature guest speakers from other Christian traditions (e.g. charismatic evangelical) and Jewish and Islamic scholars.
a. Speak Out!
This workshop is subtitled, ‘How to articulate our faith, and why’. To live an abundant life, Christians must reclaim their faith and be able to relate its meaning and its joys to others. Participants study why we should openly and respectfully share our faith, and how we can do so positively with people of other faiths and none. The Foundation say that 'Speak Out!' is intended to "help people of faith to understand the need for us to be able to speak about our faith to others, especially in today's increasingly fragmented world, and to guide people in how to speak out whilst retaining respect for people of other faiths, or none."
“Christians must be able to speak out with authority about their faith and how it applies to the real issues of the day,” says Nadim Nassar, the Director of the Awareness Foundation and author of the course materials.
The workshop, which features powerful videos with speakers from the three Abrahamic faiths, enables participants over half a day to understand the importance of their own role in spreading the message that faith matters, and that the true values of the Abrahamic faiths are love, forgiveness, respect and understanding.
== Course materials == Each module is packaged as DVD which contains the teaching videos, a course leader's book (approximately 32 pages) plus study sheets for those attending the course. These modules are available without charge within the UK.<ref>Awareness Course on the Awareness Foundation's website: {{cite web|url=http://www.awareness-foundation.co.uk/index.php/course |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928072143/http://www.awareness-foundation.co.uk/index.php/course |archivedate=2013-09-28 |df= }}</ref>
== Personnel == [[Michael Marshall (bishop)|Michael Marshall]] is President of the Awareness Foundation and [[Nadim Nassar]] is director. They are co-founders of the Awareness Foundation and co-authors of the Awareness Course. The director of the Awareness Course is the foundation's operations director, St John Wright, who has been with the Awareness Foundation since 2004; he is the son of British jazz guitarist [[Denny Wright]].

The '''Bahá'í Faith and Native Americans''' has a history reaching back to the lifetime of [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] and has multiplied its relationships across the Americas. Individuals have joined the religion and institutions have been founded to serve Native Americans and conversely have Native Americans serve on Bahá'í institutions. By 1963 Bahá'í sources claim members of some 83 tribes of Native Americans had joined the religion.{{cite book | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844–1963: Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953–1963 |publisher = [[Hand of the Cause|Hands of the Cause]] Residing in the Holy Land |year=1963 |location=Haifa, Israel | page = 19 | url = http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63&chapter=1#22 | isbn = }} In North America diversification is an ever-present theme in Bahá'í history. Native American Indians have been attracted to the [[Bahá'í Faith]] in increasing numbers since the 1940s; currently there are several thousand Indian and [[Eskimo]] Bahá'ís, especially in rural Alaska and among the [[Navajo Nation|Navajo]] and [[Lakota people|Lakota]] peoples.{{Cite book | editor-last = Miller |editor-first =Timothy | last =Stockman | first = Robert H. | title = America's alternative religions |contribution = The American Baha'i Community in the Nineties | contribution-url=http://bahai-library.com/stockman_american_community_nineties | publisher = SUNY Press |year= 1995 |location=Albany, NY, USA| pages = | url =https://books.google.com/?id=og_u0Re1uwUC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA243#v=onepage&q=&f=false| isbn = 978-0-7914-2397-4}} Among the Central and South American indigenous there are also substantial populations of native Bahá'ís. There is an estimate of some 8,000 [[Guaymi]] Bahá'is in the area of Panama,{{Cite journal |last=International Community |first=Bahá'í |author-link=Bahá'í International Community |title=In Panama, some Guaymis blaze a new path |journal=One Country |volume=1994 |issue=October–December |date=October–December 1994 |url=http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-1-18.html |access-date=2010-05-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140802031749/http://info.bahai.org/article-1-8-1-18.html# |archive-date=2014-08-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }} about 10% of the population of Guaymi in Panama.{{cite web |title=Guaymi |work=Data Map > All Affinity Blocs / People Clusters > Affinity Bloc: Latin–Caribbean Americans > People Cluster: South American Indigenous |publisher=Joshua Project – A ministry of the U.S. Center for World Mission |date=2008-06-09 |url=http://www.joshuaproject.net/peoples.php?rop3=103515 |accessdate=2008-07-06}} An informal summary of the [[Wayuu]] (a tribe living in [[La Guajira Desert]]) community in 1971 showed about 1000 Bahá'ís.{{cite journal |title=Mass Teaching is the only way to tell the people in time |journal=Bahá'í News |date=June 1971 |number=483 |page=23}} The largest population of Bahá'ís in South America is in [[Demographics of Bolivia|Bolivia]], a country whose population is estimated to be 55%–70% indigenous and 30%–42% [[Mestizo]], with a Bahá'í population estimated at 206,000 in 2005 according to the [[Association of Religion Data Archives]].{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | accessdate = 2009-07-04}} ==Native religion== ===Acceptance of spiritual founders=== [[Shoghi Effendi]], head of the religion 1921–1957, stated: "The fundamental principle enunciated by [[Bahá'u'lláh]], the followers of his Faith firmly believe, is that religious truth is not absolute but relative, that Divine Revelation is a continuous and progressive process, that all the great religions of the world are divine in origin, that their basic principles are in complete harmony, that their aims and purposes are one and the same, that their teachings are but facets of one truth, that their functions are complementary, that they differ only in the nonessential aspects of their doctrines, and that their missions represent successive stages in the spiritual evolution of human society."{{Cite book |last=Effendi |first=Shoghi |authorlink=Shoghi Effendi |title=The Promised Day Is Come |publisher=US Bahá'í Publishing Trust |year=1980 |edition=revised |page=v |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/PDC/pdc-1.html#gr1}}
In principle, a Bahá'í can certainly affirm that Messengers of God have indeed been sent to all peoples, according to Bahá'í belief, but that there is simply no conclusive way to attest legendary culture heroes individually. Under no circumstances does this prevent a real appreciation of such legends, and of the spiritual and cultural values enshrined in them. Thus, Bahá'í authorities may consider adding the ''category'' of (rather than ''names'' of) Messengers of God to First Nations, or Messengers of God to Indigenous Peoples. The problem now is no longer the principle, but rather the question of ''names''.{{Cite journal|last=Buck |first=Christopher |title=Native Messengers of God in Canada? A test case for Baha'i universalism |journal=The Bahá'í Studies Review |volume= |issue= |pages=97–132 |publisher=Association for Bahá'í Studies English-Speaking Europe |location=London |year=1996 |url=https://www.msu.edu/~buckc/Buck_PDFs/Buck_Native_1996.pdf |accessdate=2009-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719111713/https://www.msu.edu/~buckc/Buck_PDFs/Buck_Native_1996.pdf |archivedate=2013-07-19 |df= }}
The National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Canada took a position of advocacy on behalf of [[First Nations]] Canadians in its formal submission to the [[Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples]] in the fall of 1993 on behalf of indigenous people (not in relation to their religion, per se.) Bahá'í [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] to regions with aboriginal peoples have extended [[Bahá'í Faith and the unity of religion|Bahá'í universalism]] in religion to a recognition of the richness and authenticity of native cultural values. Individual Bahá'ís are free to express their own understanding, but this does not imply endorsement by the institutions of the religion though such recognition has been supported by local Bahá'í policy validating the concept of First Nations [[Manifestations of God]]. Explicit recognition of individual native messengers of God has yet to be formalised in Bahá'í doctrine. The quote from an authenticated source most directly reflecting on the issue is: {{quote|In ancient times the people of America were, through their northern regions, close to Asia, that is, separated from Asia by a strait. For this reason, it hath been said that crossing had occurred. There are other signs which indicate communication. As to places whose people were not informed of the appearance of Prophets, such people are excused. In the Qur'án it hath been revealed: 'We will not chastise them if they had not been sent a Messenger' (Q. 17:15). Undoubtedly in those regions the Call of God must have been raised in ancient times, but it hath been forgotten now.}} In this particular context, the expression "Call of God" ({{lang|fa|nidá-yi iláhí}}) is a transparent, according to Christopher Buck, reference to Prophets of God and who give [[revelation]]. Scholars like Susan Maneck{{Cite newsgroup | title = Review of Christopher Buck's "Native Messengers of God in Canada?: A test case for Bahá'í universalism" | author = Susan Maneck | date = September 4, 2003 | newsgroup =''Baha'i Studies'' |url=http://www.mail-archive.com/bahai-st@list.jccc.net/msg00432.html | accessdate = 2010-05-22}} and William Collins{{Cite journal | last =Collins | first = William P. | title = Commentary on Christopher Buck's "Native Messengers of God in Canada?: A test case for Bahá'í universalism" | journal = The Bahá'í Studies Review | volume = 08 | issue = 1998 | pages = | publisher = | location = | year = 1998 | url =http://bahai-library.com/bsr/bsr08/831_commentaries.htm | issn = |accessdate = 2010-05-22}} have taken note of the strength of this quote. However the language is not specific. The [[Universal House of Justice]] notes that "The Bahá'í Teachings do not explicitly confirm, nor do they rule out, the possibility that Messengers of God have appeared in the Americas. In the absence of a clear Text the Universal House of Justice has no basis for issuing the kind of statement you propose which would confirm, "in principle, that God sent Manifestations to the indigenous peoples of the Americas."" Nevertheless the figure of Deganawida, [[The Great Peacemaker]], is mentioned as a leading example in scholarly research;{{Cite conference | first = Aram | last = Gomez | title = The Tree of Peace and the Coming of Bahá'u'llah | booktitle =Irfan Colloquia | pages = | conference = `Irfán Colloquium |date = March 25–27, 1994 | location = Bahá'í National Center: Wilmette, Illinois, US | url =http://irfancolloquia.org/2/gomez_tree | accessdate = 2010-05-22}} others mentioned by individuals include [[Quetzalcoatl]] and [[Viracocha]].{{Cite journal | last = Buck | first = Christopher | title = Bahá'í Universalism & Native Prophets| journal = Studies in the Bábí and Bahá'í Religions| volume = 13; Reason and Revelation: New Directions in Bahá'í Thought| editor-last = Fazel | editor-first = Seena | editor2-last = Danesh| editor2-first = John | pages = 172–201 | publisher = Kalimát Press | location =Los Angeles | year = 2002 | url =http://christopherbuck.com/Buck_PDFs/Buck_Native-Prophets_2002.pdf | issn = | accessdate = 2010-05-22}} [[David Ruhe]], a former member of the Universal House of Justice, has written mentioning his own view of Deganawida as a Prophet.{{Cite journal |last=Ruhe |first = David S. | title = A New Evolution: Religious Bonding for World Unity | journal = Journal of Bahá'í Studies | volume = 06 | issue = 4 | pages =45–57 | publisher = the Association for Bahá'í Studies – North America | location = | year = 1995 | url = http://www.bahai-studies.ca/journal/past-issues | issn = | accessdate = 2010-05-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100527001611/http://www.bahai-studies.ca/journal/past-issues| archivedate= 27 May 2010 | deadurl= no}} Since no individual or institution can add to Bahá'í scripture it is impossible to add a specific name to a list of accepted [[Manifestation of God|Manifestations of God]] that would be binding on all Bahá'ís and Bahá'í institutions. However individuals and institutions may accept for their own purposes that various cultural heroes may have been in fact a [[Manifestation of God]] and Bahá'ís and institutions of the religion can accept the fact that sacred Indian tradition has mentioned specific names for individuals acting in the role of a [[Prophet]].{{Cite journal |last = Addison | first = Donald Francis | last2 = Buck | first2 = Christopher | title = Messengers of God in North America Revisited: An Exegesis of "Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablet to Amír Khán | journal = Online Journal of Bahá'í Studies | volume = 01 | pages = 180–270 | publisher =Association for Bahá'í Studies English-Speaking Europe | location = London | year = 2007 | url =http://bahaistudies.net/onlinejournal/OJBS_1_Buck_Addison_MessengersofGod.pdf | ISSN= 1177-8547 | accessdate = 2009-12-06}} ===Interpretation of prophecy=== In 1986 North American Bahá'í Lee Brown gave a talk at the 1986 Bahá'í ''Continental Indigenous Council'' held at [[Tanana Valley]] Fairgrounds, [[Fairbanks]], Alaska, which was recorded{{Cite web | last = Brown | first = Lee | title = Native American Indian prophecies – Lee Brown | work = | publisher = | year = 1986 | url =https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CKQ9mkyTSqk | accessdate = 2012-11-10}} and transcribed{{cite conference | first = Lee | last = Brown | title = North American Indian Prophecies |booktitle = Continental Indigenous Council | publisher = Bahá'í Academic Library Online | year = 1986 | url =http://bahai-library.com/brown_american_indian_prophecies | accessdate = 2009-12-05}}—it includes his interpretation of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]], especially [[Hopi]], prophecies. Brown also appeared with Martha Many Grey Horses on a Bahá'í program discussing these prophecies.{{Cite episode | title = Native American Indian prophecies – Lee Brown and Martha Many Grey Horses | episodelink = | url =https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R8LUogwVDk4 | series = The Spiritual Revolution}} [[Guaymi]] Bahá'ís have stated there are prophecies from their own tribe's religion that they interpret to relate to the Bahá'í Faith. The prophecies of the [[Chilam Balam]] have been examined as well. There has been comment among prominent Bahá'ís about the [[White Buffalo Calf Woman]] and the appearance of the [[white buffalo]].{{Cite news | title = The Return of the "White Buffalo Calf Woman": Prophecy of the Lakota | newspaper = Bahá'í News | publisher = US Bahá'í National center | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/newspapers/1995/000089.html| accessdate = 2010-05-15}} Chief Albert Isaac of [[Aishihik]] is recorded as having identified a [[Bahá'í Faith on life after death|near death experience]] of his in 1957 with the Bahá'í Faith.{{cite journal |last=Echevarria |first=Lynn |title=A new skin for an old drum: changing contexts of Yukon Aboriginal Baha'i storytelling |journal=Northern Review |volume=29 |issue=Fall 2008 |pages=39–55 |year=2008 |location=Eugene, Oregon |url=http://bahai-library.com/echevarria_aboriginal_bahai_storytelling |accessdate=2013-12-17}} ==Contacting the indigenous== ===First contact=== The first dated contact between the Bahá'í Faith and Indigenous Americans was second hand through the life of [[Honoré Jackson]] who had been involved in a [[First Nations]] protest movement in Canada circa the early 1880s and then in the later 1890s joined the religion but after some efforts in Canada in the New York area he was not much heard of after circa 1910.{{cite book|author=Will C. van den Hoonaard|title=The Origins of the Bahá’í Community of Canada, 1898-1948|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ntLfAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA18|date=30 October 2010|publisher=Wilfrid Laurier Univ. Press|isbn=978-1-55458-706-3|pages=18–35, 43–63}} ===`Abdu'l-Bahá=== In 1912 then head of the religion [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] took a [[`Abdu'l-Bahá's journeys to the West|journey to the West]] from what was then Palestine. On one leg of his trips as he was leaving Canada, on the way back to the States, and he traveled through several villages. As the train passed through the town of [[Belleville, Ontario]], a four-year-old [[Mohawk nation|Mohawk]] boy, Jimmy Loft, was sitting on a fence as the train passed. `Abdu'l-Bahá took that moment to stand up and, facing the window, smile and wave. Loft was so surprised he toppled off the fence. In May 1948 he became one of the first native American Bahá'ís of Canada. ====Talk at the Maxwell's Home in Montreal==== During his [[`Abdu'l-Bahá's journeys to the West|tour of North America]], `Abdu'l-Bahá gave a talk on September 2, 1912 in the Montreal home of [[William Sutherland Maxwell]] (later named a [[Hand of the Cause]] by [[Shoghi Effendi]] in 1951) and [[May Maxwell]], the parents of [[Rúhíyyih Khanum|Mary Maxwell]], the future Amatu'l-Bahá Rúhíyyih Khánum, wife of Shoghi Effendi.{{cite book |last=[['Abdu'l-Baha]] |first= |date=1982 |title=Promulgation of Universal Peace: Talks Delivered by Abdu'l Baha during His Visit to the United States and Canada in 1912 | url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/PUP/ |chapter-url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/PUP/pup-101.html | chapter= 2 September 1912, Talk at Home of Mr. and Mrs. William Sutherland Maxwell, 716 Pine Avenue West, Montreal, Canada | location= |publisher=Bahai Publishing Trust, 2nd Edition |isbn=978-0877431725}}
Consider this Canadian country during the early history of Montreal when the land was in its wild, uncultivated and natural condition. The soil was unproductive, rocky and almost uninhabitable—vast forests stretching in every direction. What invisible power caused this great metropolis to spring up amid such savage and forbidding conditions? It was the human mind. Therefore, nature and the effect of nature's laws were imperfect. The mind of man remedied and removed this imperfect condition, until now we behold a great city instead of a savage unbroken wilderness. Before the coming of Columbus America itself was a wild, uncultivated expanse of primeval forest, mountains and rivers—a very world of nature. Now it has become the world of man. It was dark, forbidding and savage; now it has become illumined with a great civilization and prosperity. Instead of forests, we behold productive farms, beautiful gardens and prolific orchards. Instead of thorns and useless vegetation, we find flowers, domestic animals and fields awaiting harvest. If the world of nature were perfect, the condition of this great country would have been left unchanged.
====Tablet to Amr Khan==== A tablet of Abdu'l-Bahá's undated but certainly before his death in 1921 and probably after 1892, is called the Tablet to Amr Khan, in which he acknowledges that "the Call of God" must have arisen in the Americas though its spiritual affect had been forgotten.{{cite journal | author=Christopher Buck | title = Native Messengers of God in Canada?: A Test Case for Bahá'í Universalism | journal =Bahá'í Studies Review | volume =6 | pages =97–133 | publisher = Association for Bahá'í Studies English-Speaking Europe | location = London, UK | date = 1996 | url =http://bahai-library.com/buck_native_messengers | accessdate =Oct 28, 2015 }} ====`Abdu'l-Bahá's Tablets of the Divine Plan==== `Abdu'l-Bahá also wrote a series of letters, or [[tablets (religious)|tablets]], to the followers of the religion in the [[United States]] in 1916-1917; these letters were compiled together in the book ''[[Tablets of the Divine Plan]]''. The sixth of the tablets was the first to mention [[Latin America]]n regions and was written on April 8, 1916, but was delayed in being presented in the United States until 1919—after the end of the [[World War I|First World War]] and the [[Spanish flu]]. The sixth tablet was translated and presented by [[Mirza Ahmad Sohrab]] on April 4, 1919, and published in ''[[Star of the West (Bahá'í magazine)|Star of the West]]'' magazine on December 12, 1919.{{cite book |last1=Abbas |first1=`Abdu'l-Bahá |others=Mirza Ahmad Sohrab, trans. and comments. | title = Tablets, Instructions and Words of Explanation |date=April 1919 |url=http://bahai-library.com/abdulbaha_tablets_instructions_explanation}} After mentioning the need for the message of the religion to visit the Latin American countries `Abdu'l-Bahá continued:
Attach great importance to the indigenous population of America. For these souls may be likened unto the ancient inhabitants of the Arabian Peninsula, who, prior to the Mission of Muḥammad, were like unto savages. When the light of Muḥammad shone forth in their midst, however, they became so radiant as to illumine the world. Likewise, these Indians, should they be educated and guided, there can be no doubt that they will become so illumined as to enlighten the whole world ...{{cite book |author = `Abdu'l-Bahá |authorlink = `Abdu'l-Bahá |origyear = 1916-17 |year = 1991 |title = Tablets of the Divine Plan |edition = Paperback |publisher = Bahá'í Publishing Trust |location = Wilmette, IL |isbn = 0-87743-233-3 |url=http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/ab/TDP/tdp-14.html.iso8859-1#gr7 |page=104}}
Following the Tablets and about the time of `Abdu'l-Bahá's passing in 1921, a few other Bahá'ís began moving to, or at least visiting, Latin or South America.{{cite book | last = Lamb | first = Artemus | title = The Beginnings of the Bahá'í Faith in Latin America:Some Remembrances, English Revised and Amplified Edition | publisher = M L VanOrman Enterprises |date=November 1995 | location = West Linn, Oregon | url = http://bahai-library.com/lamb_bahai_latin_america}} First [[Martha Root]]{{cite thesis | first = Jiling | last = Yang | title = In Search of Martha Root: An American Bahá'í Feminist and Peace Advocate in the early Twentieth Century |publisher=[[Georgia State University]] |date=January 2007 | url = http://digitalarchive.gsu.edu/wsi_theses/11/ |format=pdf |accessdate=2008-06-30}} followed by [[Leonora Armstrong]]{{Citation | title = In Memoriam | journal = The Bahá'í World | volume = XVIII | publisher = Bahá'í World Centre | pages = 733–736 | year = 1986 | url = http://bahai-library.com/books/bw18/720-748.html | isbn = 0-85398-234-1 | author = prepared under the supervision of the Universal House of Justice.}} were among the first to make this trips before 1928. ===1920s=== The next known contact between Indians and Bahá'ís is the case of Albert T. Freeman, also known as Gai-wah-go-wah, who was an award winning orator*{{cite news | title =Sioux Indian DePauw's man in state oratorical contest | newspaper =The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =28 | date =3 February 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/966873/albert_freeman_to_state_orator_contest/ | accessdate = Oct 28, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =Indian orator, DePauw student, wins contest | newspaper =The Indianapolis News | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =13 | date = 24 February 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/966901/albert_freeman_wins_state_contest/ | accessdate = Oct 28, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title =The Winning Orators | newspaper =Fort Wayne Daily News | location =Fort Wayne, Indiana | page =9 | date =14 April 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/966918/albert_freeman_among_winners/ | accessdate = Oct 28, 2015 }} as an Indian of the [[Lakota people]] in 1917.{{cite news | title =Indian Lore Program of Department Club has many features | newspaper =The Indianapolis Star | location =Indianapolis, Indiana | page =6 | date =18 November 1917 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/966789/albert_freeman_performance_mistakenly/ | accessdate = Oct 28, 2015 }} He was soon a graduate of [[Depauw University]] and visible as a Christian and an actor.{{cite news | title =Brazil High School presents ... | newspaper =The DePauw Daily | location = | page =3 (3rd col) | date =Dec 11, 1917 | url =http://digital.library.depauw.edu:8080/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/dpupub&CISOPTR=101662&REC=4 | accessdate = Oct 28, 2015}} Around 1920-1924 he was a student at [[University of Southern California]]{{cite news | title = Methodist Church | newspaper =The Van Nuys News | location =Van Nuys, California | page =4 | date =9 June 1921 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/clip/965637/addressperformance_by_albert_t_freeman/ | accessdate = Oct 28, 2015 }} * {{cite news | title = Indian speaks tonight | newspaper = Logansport Pharos-Tribune | location =Logansport, Indiana | page =8 | date =3 April 1924 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/clip/965684/albert_freeman_performance_the/ | accessdate = Oct 28, 2015}} and took up the [[Chautauqua]] educational speaker platforms similar to [[Nipo T.
